qas.question: When did the ACLU first challenge the Patriot Act?
What rights did the ACLU say the Patriot Act violated?

answers.text: First Amendment rights, Fourth Amendment rights, and right to due process

qas.question: What did Section 215 of the Patriot Act allow the FBI to search?

answers.text: a person's business, bookstore, and library records

qas.question: Who passed symbolic resolutions against the Patriot Act?

answers.text: governing bodies in a number of communities

plausible_answers.text: First Amendment rights, Fourth Amendment rights, and right to due process

qas.question: What has governmental authority said the laws remove restrictions from?

plausible_answers.text: a person's business, bookstore, and library records

qas.question: What did Section 215 allow the ACLU to inspect?

context: <b6_0>Political interest groups<b6_0/> have stated that these laws remove important restrictions on governmental authority, and are a dangerous encroachment on civil liberties, possible unconstitutional violations of the Fourth Amendment. On <a0_0><b5_0>30 July 2003<b5_0/><a0_0/>, the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) filed the first legal challenge against Section 215 of the Patriot Act, claiming that it allows <b8_0>the FBI<b8_0/> to violate a citizen's <a1_0><b4_0>First Amendment rights, Fourth Amendment rights, and right to due process<b4_0/><a1_0/>, by granting the government the right to search <a2_0><b7_0>a person's business, bookstore, and library records<b7_0/><a2_0/> in a terrorist investigation, without disclosing to the individual that records were being searched. Also, <a3_0>governing bodies in a number of communities<a3_0/> have passed symbolic resolutions against the act.
